FRIDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1942

Governor Harold E Stassen, of Minnesota, in a
speech at Town hall, New.
Early Views
York city, last Friday outOn the Peace
lined a seven-point program
for post-war world government. Although the metropolitan papers have ignored
Mx Stassen's speech, we feel that any such discussion
of the pertinent problems of the peace deserves comment.
Mr Stassen's principal idea is that the United Nations
should form the nucleus of an international government to control the entire post-war world. The Units.d
Nations would exert temporary control over the Axis
nations without 'inhuman vengeance against the populations.' This concept is in line with an opinion which
many people have held that the world will and should
be controlled by an international government rather
than by many disunited ones.
To establish such a government would require the
overcoming of more than administrative difficulties. It
would require the breaking--down of deeply founded
distinctions of race, environment, language, and local
tradition. Mr Stassen's proposal that production,
economy, government, education, all be put on a worldwide basis will go much farther toward developing international unity than did the League of Nations; but
he must further recognize that cultural unity must be
achieved. This task may be impossible; it will certainly take careful, intelligent planning and many years.
Another principal weakness in Mr Stassen's proposal is his point that the Axis nations should be disarmed, while the United Nations remain armed. Although such action may be inevitable in the process of
developing international organization, such moves
toward inequality should be avoided; and if inequalities
must arise, they should be rectified as soon as possible.
Although the peace is probably far in the future,
it is not too early to begin thinking about it. Goveinor
Stassen's points are promising of an intelligent outlook
for peacetime administration.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE

Vags Give 'The Three Sisters'
Fair Version Masterfully Handled
Of 'Candid'
By JAMES APPLEGATE
As a whole the Vagabond theater's
production of Candida, by George
Bernard Shaw, is only mediocre; but
the performance is well worth seeing
not only because of the good points
that the Vagabond interpretation
does have, but also because of the
excellencies of Mr Shaw's drama.
Roger Maxwell, as James Morrell,
the idealistic and socialistic Anglican
pastor, gives a finished and understanding portrayal.
Mabel Scott
Georgi, as his wife Candida, is a
poor partner for him; while she
speaks and moves with adequate expression, she shows practically no
emotion. She fails to convince the
audience that Candida's charms are
sufficient cause for the action that
centers around her.
Moore, as Marchbanks, the tragically poetic eighteen year old, rises
to no variations of emotion. His
medium of character portrayal is a
constant pained expression and a
stiff walk; his speech alternates only
between
dreaminess and frenzy.
Mary Alvey, as Miss Prossy, is a
disappointment, considering her usual
excellence; she is comic, but at times
she fails to convey Shaw's nuance by
continuing at too rapid a pace.
Martin Murray, as the scurrulotis
Mr Burgess, and Arthur Hazard, as
the apprentice pastor, are quite good
in their small parts.
Much of the deficiency in the acting, as well as in the staging, can
probably be attributed to poor direction by Greg Mooney. Miss Alvey's
rapid delivery, in particular, may
well be the fault of the director.
Mr Dobson's staging is generally adequate, but it seldom adds to
the action of the play and at times
it is clumsy. His use of characters
talking into the wall is more annoying than dramatic, and he often fails
to make evident the motivation for a
character's action. Three or four of

By AMos TAYLOR
Katharine Cornell's revival of Chekhov's The Three Sisters represents
first of all a masterful direction job
on the part of Guthrie McClintic.
The task of translating the badly
written plays of Chekhov into vital,
pulsing stage action, and of render-

Editorial Note: We are reprinting
this article from the `Goucher College
Weekly' of November 20, 1942.

Fireside Parties
Are More Fun!!!
Not a new idea, but one even more
delightful this year than ever, is the
custom of impromptu fireside gatherings in the room of our head of hall
at Mary Fisher.
Miss Tarrey, captain and guide of
West House has had several of these
affairs in her apartment, each more
enjoyable than the other.
What could be more pleasant on a
Friday evening with the wind howling like a demon outside, than a
blazing fire in the hearth, hot chocolate, raisins, candy and a jolly company? Much good talk enlivens the
evening, and campus gossip is mutually exchanged.
Here's one vote for bigger and
more numerous fireside parties!

ing eloquently the warm, sweet tears,
which are always implicit in Chekhov
but never explicit, is one that can be
achieved only by the most imaginative, patient, and, to some degree,
autocratic directors. Mr McClintic
has triumphed brilliantly.
The directorial triumph is all the
more brilliant when the all-primadonna cast is considered. Although
acting on the part of individuals was
certainly not on an equal plane, no
one made an effort to steal a scene.
The actors' visions of their roles have
been synthesized to a degree of complete saturation of a single mood;
the play moves with the effortlessness
that is the product of hundreds of
hours of hard work.
Miss Cornell's part is not the largest in the play but it is the best performed.
Judith Anderson, Dennis
King, and Edmund (The Wookey)
Gwenn contributed the other unforgetable characterizations of this production. Only half a notch below
them are Gertrude Musgrove, Eric
Dressler, and Tom Powers. The remaining members of the cast contribute performances of exceptional
quality, including
Ruth
Gordon,
whose inclination to be a nasty old
villainess strikes the few false notes
in the play.
We will not attempt to summarize
the plot of The Three Sisters,'riga
is the interplay of psychological
forces; but it must be observed that
the thread of these subtle developments is never lost or distorted by
wrongly emphasized acting or direction; the oddly pathetic personal
tragedy with which the play ends
seems more overwhelming than all
the cosmic blood and thunder written for the stage since Aeschylus.
For those interested in virtuosity
rather than ideas, we will say that
this production of The Three Sisters
contains the most brilliant handling

According to Lorin Stieff, president of the Interfraternity board,
interfraternity basketball will get
under way before the Christmas holidays, although no definite date has
been set for the first game. It is
likely that the teams will be divided
into two leagues, but the leagues will
not be the same as last year, since
three fraternities have left the campus. The winners of these two divisions will play for the championship
at the annual Gymboree.
Contests will be held on Saturday
afternoons, and every team will play
once a week. Games will start at
2, 3, and 4 o'clock; two games will
be held each hour on parallel courts
in the gym. }o-"need for any
changes in„rules has arisen, so 19411942 rules will remain in effect.
ynder these regulations, all fraternity men except members of the

to play.

Sigma Delta, Delta Phi, Alpha Tat
Omega, Phi Epsilon Pi, Alpha Delta
Phi, Delta Upsilon, Sigma Phi Epsilon, and Beta Theta Pi. It is probable that Phi Chi, medical fraternity,
will also be represented, as they
iyez'e last year, but will not be eligible for the playoffs. In last year's
finals, Alpha Delta Phi beat Phi
Gamma Delta, 23-19, to win the
championship.

Membership /
Reaches 110
Membership in the Rifle club has
now reached 110, it was announced
this week by Lieutenant Oscar L
Helm, instructor in charge. The
club meets twice weekly. The primary purpose of the Rifle club is
the promotion of good marksmanship
and the training of members for the
Rifle team. Members are taught to
fire in prone, kneeling, and standing
positions. Such training is of help
to them in their ROTC course.
Before Lt Helm took over the direction of the Rifle club, it 'was for
three years under the guidance of
Major "ordyce E C Campbell, who
brou ht the Rifle team up from
one semester while his Cl
fifteenth to sixth place in the competition for the Hearst Rifle Trophy.
During the time of Major Campbell's
tutelage of the club, its membership
rose from 20 to the present number
of 110.
The schedule of meetings for the
Rifle club are posted on the /ROTC
bulletin board. Anyone interested
it should see Sergeant David Foley.

Scene: Mount Olympus.

Four upperclassmen and an October freshman compose the team
which will start for Hopkins when the
Blue Jays open their basketball season tonight at 8.30 against the
American university Eagles in Washington.
Captain Bud Thanhauser, veteran
first string player, and freshman Toni
Price will be at the guard positions;
Ken McIntosh and Dick Shaffner at
the forward posts; and George Riepe
at center.
Three men who saw action last
year as reserves—Lionel Zheutlin,
Pete Stern, and Danny Greenbaum-will be on the sidelines tonight because of injuries. The balance of the
squad will be chOsen from among the
following: Prank Rudo, Paul Aduhm, Jerry
Lowengard, Gordon
Strate, Frank Roberts, Hal Silberman,
Marshall,
George
George
Thaler, Mel Lewis, Conrad Miller,
Al Loreck, Manny Goldberg, Elliot
Rosenberg, Jim Cantrell, Harvey
Weldon, and George Kennard.
American university has played
Georgetown, Catholic, and Baltimore
universities and the Curtis Bay Coast
Guard quintets thus far this season.
The Eagles will start a squad averaging over six feet and including
four veterans. Records show that
Captain George ZUras and Bart Fugler, forwards, have made over 50 per
cent of all points scored by the team
to date. Other members of the first
five are Ed Babbitt and Burke Hertz,
guards, and Bob Fugler, center.
Blue Jay coach Gardner Mallonee,
commenting on prospects for the
season, said, 'It's a shame that injuries had to hit so hard just before
the American game, because the
Eagles have a heads-up unit that
knows how to jump on the breaks.
But you can bet that the boys will be
in there battling—come what may.'

Expecting strong opposition from
Navy, Haverford, and Gettysburg, the
Hopkins wrestling squad will first
see competitive action when it opens
a schedule of eight matches after
the Christmas holidays. Without the
services of Captain Bob Rosenthal
and Nick Stamatacos, the team will
depend on a few returning veterans
and several newcomers to fill the
various weight divisions.
Practice was begun only last week,
and Coach Dick Hoover stated that
the prospects of the team will be better when the men get into shape.
The team is looking for new candidates from among the June and
October freshmen. If Dick Marshall,
former Gilman high school star, and
145 pound interscholastic champion
last year, reports for practice, the
Jays will have less difficulty in tilling
the vacant weight classes. At the
present time, Marshall is eligible to
wrestle, but is teaching the sport at
Gilman.
Returning Hopkins veterans include Ed Lauterbach, Ray Pohl, Ted

Joe Schapiro, Pete Gaillard, Larry
Middlekamp, and HarrY Leopold are
newcomers who are showing promise.

Debating Council to Meet on Monday;
Members to Present Negative Briefs;
Katz, Wolff, Kerpelman, Frech Debate
The next regular meeting of the
debating council will be held on Monday afternoon, December 14, in room
108 Gilman hall at 5 pm. In preparation for that meeting, all members
of and candidates for the council are
required to draw up negative briefs
for the official topic of this year.
These briefs are to be addressed to
Sidney Katz, box 525, and are to be
placed in that box before Friday
afternoon, 4 pm. The topic is given
in full below.

a trip which will take them to
Georgetown university, William and
Mary college, and the University of
Virginia. They returned from the
trip yesterday. None of the debates
were officially judged, since it is the
common practice for intercollegiate
teams to have non-decision debates.
The reasons for this are numerous,
the main ones being: (1) that most
judges are biased on one aide or the
other of the argument, and are unable, despite effort, to treat the
issue objectively, (2) that many
judges are biased in favor of one or
the other of the competing schools,
(3) that many judges have a particular liking for a certain type of presentation or a certain type of argument, and (4) that there is no way
for a judge to determine the proper
balance of presentation and points of
argument when deciding a debate.
Kerpelman will debate with Roy
Frech on the same topic in a debate
with Loyola college's freshman debating team at Loyola next Monday
afternoon. This too will be a nondecision debate.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1942

Governor Harold E Stassen, of Minnesota, in a
speech at Town hall, New.
Early Views
York city, last Friday outOn the Peace
lined a seven-point program
for post-war world government. Although the metropolitan papers have ignored
Mx Stassen's speech, we feel that any such discussion
of the pertinent problems of the peace deserves comment.
Mr Stassen's principal idea is that the United Nations
should form the nucleus of an international government to control the entire post-war world. The Units.d
Nations would exert temporary control over the Axis
nations without 'inhuman vengeance against the populations.' This concept is in line with an opinion which
many people have held that the world will and should
be controlled by an international government rather
than by many disunited ones.
To establish such a government would require the
overcoming of more than administrative difficulties. It
would require the breaking--down of deeply founded
distinctions of race, environment, language, and local
tradition. Mr Stassen's proposal that production,
economy, government, education, all be put on a worldwide basis will go much farther toward developing international unity than did the League of Nations; but
he must further recognize that cultural unity must be
achieved. This task may be impossible; it will certainly take careful, intelligent planning and many years.
Another principal weakness in Mr Stassen's proposal is his point that the Axis nations should be disarmed, while the United Nations remain armed. Although such action may be inevitable in the process of
developing international organization, such moves
toward inequality should be avoided; and if inequalities
must arise, they should be rectified as soon as possible.
Although the peace is probably far in the future,
it is not too early to begin thinking about it. Goveinor
Stassen's points are promising of an intelligent outlook
for peacetime administration.

Vags Give 'The Three Sisters'
Fair Version Masterfully Handled
Of 'Candid'
By JAMES APPLEGATE
As a whole the Vagabond theater's
production of Candida, by George
Bernard Shaw, is only mediocre; but
the performance is well worth seeing
not only because of the good points
that the Vagabond interpretation
does have, but also because of the
excellencies of Mr Shaw's drama.
Roger Maxwell, as James Morrell,
the idealistic and socialistic Anglican
pastor, gives a finished and understanding portrayal.
Mabel Scott
Georgi, as his wife Candida, is a
poor partner for him; while she
speaks and moves with adequate expression, she shows practically no
emotion. She fails to convince the
audience that Candida's charms are
sufficient cause for the action that
centers around her.
Moore, as Marchbanks, the tragically poetic eighteen year old, rises
to no variations of emotion. His
medium of character portrayal is a
constant pained expression and a
stiff walk; his speech alternates only
between
dreaminess and frenzy.
Mary Alvey, as Miss Prossy, is a
disappointment, considering her usual
excellence; she is comic, but at times
she fails to convey Shaw's nuance by
continuing at too rapid a pace.
Martin Murray, as the scurrulotis
Mr Burgess, and Arthur Hazard, as
the apprentice pastor, are quite good
in their small parts.
Much of the deficiency in the acting, as well as in the staging, can
probably be attributed to poor direction by Greg Mooney. Miss Alvey's
rapid delivery, in particular, may
well be the fault of the director.
Mr Dobson's staging is generally adequate, but it seldom adds to
the action of the play and at times
it is clumsy. His use of characters
talking into the wall is more annoying than dramatic, and he often fails
to make evident the motivation for a
character's action. Three or four of

Katharine Cornell's revival of Chekhov's The Three Sisters represents
first of all a masterful direction job
on the part of Guthrie McClintic.

written plays of Chekhov into vital,

Fireside Parties
Are More Fun!!!
Not a new idea, but one even more
delightful this year than ever, is the
custom of impromptu fireside gatherings in the room of our head of hall
at Mary Fisher.
Miss Tarrey, captain and guide of
West House has had several of these
affairs in her apartment, each more
enjoyable than the other.
What could be more pleasant on a
Friday evening with the wind howling like a demon outside, than a
blazing fire in the hearth, hot chocolate, raisins, candy and a jolly company? Much good talk enlivens the
evening, and campus gossip is mutually exchanged.
Here's one vote for bigger and
more numerous fireside parties!

ing eloquently the warm, sweet tears,
which are always implicit in Chekhov
but never explicit, is one that can be
achieved only by the most imaginative, patient, and, to some degree,
autocratic directors. Mr McClintic
has triumphed brilliantly.
The directorial triumph is all the
more brilliant when the all-primadonna cast is considered. Although
acting on the part of individuals was
certainly not on an equal plane, no
one made an effort to steal a scene.
The actors' visions of their roles have
been synthesized to a degree of complete saturation of a single mood;
the play moves with the effortlessness
that is the product of hundreds of
hours of hard work.
Miss Cornell's part is not the largest in the play but it is the best performed.
Judith Anderson, Dennis
King, and Edmund (The Wookey)
Gwenn contributed the other unforgetable characterizations of this production. Only half a notch below
them are Gertrude Musgrove, Eric
Dressler, and Tom Powers. The remaining members of the cast contribute performances of exceptional
quality, including
Ruth
Gordon,
whose inclination to be a nasty old
villainess strikes the few false notes
in the play.
We will not attempt to summarize
the plot of The Three Sisters,'riga
is the interplay of psychological
forces; but it must be observed that
the thread of these subtle developments is never lost or distorted by
wrongly emphasized acting or direction; the oddly pathetic personal
tragedy with which the play ends
seems more overwhelming than all
the cosmic blood and thunder written for the stage since Aeschylus.
For those interested in virtuosity
rather than ideas, we will say that
this production of The Three Sisters
contains the most brilliant handling

Interfraternity Cage
Contests to Begin
Before Holidays
According to Lorin Stieff, president of the Interfraternity board,
interfraternity basketball will get
under way before the Christmas holidays, although no definite date has
been set for the first game. It is
likely that the teams will be divided
into two leagues, but the leagues will
not be the same as last year, since
three fraternities have left the campus. The winners of these two divisions will play for the championship
at the annual Gymboree.
Contests will be held on Saturday
afternoons, and every team will play
once a week. Games will start at
2, 3, and 4 o'clock; two games will
be held each hour on parallel courts
in the gym. }o-"need for any
changes in„rules has arisen, so 19411942 rules will remain in effect.
ynder these regulations, all fraternity men except members of the
Hopkins varsity squad are eligible
to play.
The following fraternities will be
represented in competition:
Phi
Gamma Delta, Alpha Epsilon lei,
Epsilon Tau Alpha, Kap-pa Alpha, Phi
Sigma Delta, Delta Phi, Alpha Tat
Omega, Phi Epsilon Pi, Alpha Delta
Phi, Delta Upsilon, Sigma Phi Epsilon, and Beta Theta Pi. It is probable that Phi Chi, medical fraternity,
will also be represented, as they
iyez'e last year, but will not be eligible for the playoffs. In last year's
finals, Alpha Delta Phi beat Phi
Gamma Delta, 23-19, to win the
championship.

The Arts eleven defeated the Mechanical Engineers 12 to 6 in a final

championship of the-4.15 to 5.45
Tuesday-Thursday gym section. The,
victory gives the Arts team the right
to meet the champions of the Wednesday-Friday section for the intramural
gym championship next week.

Membership /
Reaches 110
Membership in the Rifle club has
now reached 110, it was announced
this week by Lieutenant Oscar L
Helm, instructor in charge. The
club meets twice weekly. The primary purpose of the Rifle club is
the promotion of good marksmanship
and the training of members for the
Rifle team. Members are taught to
fire in prone, kneeling, and standing
positions. Such training is of help
to them in their ROTC course.
Before Lt Helm took over the direction of the Rifle club, it 'was for
three years under the guidance of
Major "ordyce E C Campbell, who
brou ht the Rifle team up from
one semester while his Cl
fifteenth to sixth place in the competition for the Hearst Rifle Trophy.
During the time of Major Campbell's
tutelage of the club, its membership
rose from 20 to the present number
of 110.
The schedule of meetings for the
Rifle club are posted on the /ROTC
bulletin board. Anyone interested
it should see Sergeant David Foley.

Scene: Mount Olympus.

Four upperclassmen and an October freshman compose the team
which will start for Hopkins when the
Blue Jays open their basketball season tonight at 8.30 against the
American university Eagles in Washington.
Captain Bud Thanhauser, veteran
first string player, and freshman Toni
Price will be at the guard positions;
Ken McIntosh and Dick Shaffner at
the forward posts; and George Riepe
at center.
Three men who saw action last
year as reserves—Lionel Zheutlin,
Pete Stern, and Danny Greenbaum-will be on the sidelines tonight because of injuries. The balance of the
squad will be chOsen from among the
following: Prank Rudo, Paul Aduhm, Jerry
Lowengard, Gordon
Strate, Frank Roberts, Hal Silberman,
Marshall,
George
George
Thaler, Mel Lewis, Conrad Miller,
Al Loreck, Manny Goldberg, Elliot
Rosenberg, Jim Cantrell, Harvey
Weldon, and George Kennard.
American university has played
Georgetown, Catholic, and Baltimore
universities and the Curtis Bay Coast
Guard quintets thus far this season.
The Eagles will start a squad averaging over six feet and including
four veterans. Records show that
Captain George ZUras and Bart Fugler, forwards, have made over 50 per
cent of all points scored by the team
to date. Other members of the first
five are Ed Babbitt and Burke Hertz,
guards, and Bob Fugler, center.
Blue Jay coach Gardner Mallonee,
commenting on prospects for the
season, said, 'It's a shame that injuries had to hit so hard just before
the American game, because the
Eagles have a heads-up unit that
knows how to jump on the breaks.
But you can bet that the boys will be
in there battling—come what may.'

Expecting strong opposition from
Navy, Haverford, and Gettysburg, the
Hopkins wrestling squad will first
see competitive action when it opens
a schedule of eight matches after
the Christmas holidays. Without the
services of Captain Bob Rosenthal
and Nick Stamatacos, the team will
depend on a few returning veterans
and several newcomers to fill the
various weight divisions.
Practice was begun only last week,
and Coach Dick Hoover stated that
the prospects of the team will be better when the men get into shape.
The team is looking for new candidates from among the June and
October freshmen. If Dick Marshall,
former Gilman high school star, and
145 pound interscholastic champion
last year, reports for practice, the
Jays will have less difficulty in tilling
the vacant weight classes. At the
present time, Marshall is eligible to
wrestle, but is teaching the sport at
Gilman.

Mattern, and Mort Disney, Ed Bock,
Joe Schapiro, Pete Gaillard, Larry
Middlekamp, and HarrY Leopold are
newcomers who are showing promise.

The reasons for this are numerous,
the main ones being: (1) that most
judges are biased on one aide or the
other of the argument, and are unable, despite effort, to treat the
issue objectively, (2) that many
judges are biased in favor of one or
the other of the competing schools,
(3) that many judges have a particular liking for a certain type of presentation or a certain type of argument, and (4) that there is no way
for a judge to determine the proper
balance of presentation and points of
argument when deciding a debate.
